posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: So, I’m trying to learn everything that I need to know about Swerve Drive. I need some videos or maybe websites that you guys believe that could help me? And also I have to ask something our team will have swerve this year for the first time and do we need to have mini power module. If, so how?

posts.name: Christopher Tabor
posts.cooked:
I’ll see if I can get some good references, but here are some general considerations/responses:

Did/are you considering checking out swerve during the off season instead of during?

Watch current limits.  That hit us year 1 as we burned out one motor and almost did others as well.

Depending on type you purchased, you may need to buy extra tread and not all tread are created equal as some wares faster than others.

I assume you are referring to REV or some other brand’s mini power ports.  They are only needed if you run out of slots on your power distribution hub/board/panel.

I suggest mentioning the brand/version of swerve you have to get the best info…

Be prepared for the fact you will need to occasionally realign.  How best to do this will also differ based on product, hence why I asked what product.

Although it can depend on motors used, most swerve drive modules allow for faster speeds, especially if you were using CIM motors previously.  Therefore, I suggest starting with lower power to your motors.  We often use 2-3 speed levels normal (often 80-90%), fast (>80%), and possibly a crawl speed to prevent overshooting (often < 25%).  Not sure if the code examples below talk about that.

Additionally, as far as software goes, if you’re planning to try to get swerve working by the end of this season, I would highly recommend checking out YAGSL . It is an absolutely incredible swerve library that our team has found very useful and easy to work with. Custom swerve code is always valuable as a learning opportunity and for understanding what’s going on under the hood, but it takes longer to debug in my opinion and I’m not sure how much time you guys have got.

Having reliable code ready for when you get the hardware set up will likely make your lives easier, especially because YAGSL automatically configures all your motor controllers, encoders, etc. so you don’t have to mess with all that.

If you’re still interested in custom code/learning how the software is working, there’s an excellent series of videos about that here: https://www.youtube.com/@0ToAuto

link_counts.title: Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL

posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: We are going to use REV Robotics PDH and some team members mentioned that we have to buy REV Mini Power Module so I was questioning myself what is this module does. Thank you I believe this season we’ll be having a swerve thank you.

posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: I checked both website and the youtube channel and I’m really grateful for your help, it’ll help my team a lot thank you.

posts.name: Christopher Tabor
posts.cooked: What swerve product did you purchase?

posts.name: Christopher Tabor
posts.cooked: I should have also asked does your driver have a preference of field or robot-oriented drive?  This too may factor for the coding.

posts.name: Christopher Tabor
posts.cooked:
Black Neoprene vs Blue Nitrile Tread - Technical / Technical Discussion - Chief Delphi

This assumes you picked a swerve product with replaceable tread.  Personally, Neoprene is the best.  It provided good traction and lasted longer.  Nitrile we had to replace 2-3 times during a regional event.  With Neoprene we might replace after each regional event.

Continuing this assumption, I recommend taking off a tread, make a template, and cut and drill out some extra tread, test, and replace tread.

link_counts.title: Black Neoprene vs Blue Nitrile Tread

posts.cooked: If you are going to use YAGSL , there is a tutorial series that you can follow that walks you through all the steps of configuring your  robot to programming an autonomous using YAGSL . Super helpful if you feel lost in documentation.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
goktugyldz:

We are going to use REV Robotics PDH and some team members mentioned that we have to buy REV Mini Power Module so I was questioning myself what is this module does.

The Rev MPM is purely a convenient and safe way to divide up the bigger wires from the PDH into many small wires for sensors and other custom circuits. It can’t be used for motors, actuators, or other core control system components (RIO, Radio, PCM ), but it is perfect for things like encoders or vision systems that need (unregulated) battery voltage.

posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: We are going to use encoder specially CTR CanCoder do we still need to use MPM. I believe we don’t need to

posts.name: Goktug Yildiz
posts.cooked: Thank you a lot, I’ll make sure watch these and check the links you sent.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked: Correct, you do not need it. It does help keep your wiring nice, but there absolutely are other ways to distribute power to sensors and still comply with the rules.
